questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a hallmark of malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Cancer cells are insensitive to growth-inhibitory signals. All cancer cells are known to show around 8 fundamental physiological changes in the cell, which 
are considered as the hallmarks of cancer. These changes include the following: • Self-sufficiency in growth signals - once activated, tumors can proliferate without external 
stimuli • Insensitivity to growth-inhibitory signals - tumors do not respond to inhibitors of cell growth. 
This is attributed to the inactivation of the tumor-suppressor genes in cancer cells • Altered cellular metabolism - tumor cells switch to aerobic glycolysis, called the Warburg effect • Evasion of apoptosis • Limitless replicative potential • Sustained angiogenesis • Ability to invade and metastasis • Ability to evade the host immune response

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the Warburg effect?

options.a: Cancer cells are characterized by high levels of glucose uptake
options.b: Cancer cells convert glucose to lactic acid even in the presence of ample oxygen
options.c: Conversion of glucose to lactic acid is done via the HMP pathway
options.d: Aerobic glycolysis provides cancer cells with metabolic intermediates

questions.explanation:
Increased conversion of glucose to lactic acid is done via the glycolytic pathway (not HMP). Even in the presence of ample oxygen, cancer cells demonstrate a distinctive form of cellular 
metabolism. This is characterized by high levels of glucose uptake and increased conversion of 
glucose to lactic acid via the glycolytic pathway. This phenomenon is called the Warburg effect. Aerobic glycolysis provides rapidly dividing tumor cells with metabolic intermediates that are 
required for the synthesis of cellular components, whereas mitochondrial oxidative phosphor- 
ylation□ does not.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is false about adenomas?

options.d: They can be of non-glandular origin

questions.explanation:
Pleomorphic adenoma is an example of a mixed tumor consisting of epithelial and myoepithelial 
cells with or without stromal components. Adenomas are benign epithelial tumors. They can arise from: • Glandular cells and form glandular structures - for example, follicular adenomas of the thyroid, 
which arise from the thyroid gland and forms glandular structures • Glandular cells but form non-glandular structures - for example, heterogeneous mass of adrenal 
cortical cells growing as a solid sheet • Non-glandular cells and form glandular structures - for example, benign epithelial neoplasm that 
arises from renal tubular cells growing in the form of numerous tightly clustered small glands 207 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: All are small round blue cell tumors except:
questions.explanation:
Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor. Hemangioblastomas are tumors of central nervous system that originate from vascular tissues. 
They demonstrate the proliferation of capillaries with variable sized, closely packed, and thin 
walled vessels as seen in the image below. Small round blue cell tumors consist of small round cells that stain blue on routine H&E 
staining sections. They include: • Neuroblastoma • Retinoblastoma • Ewing's sarcoma • Wilms tumor • Rhabdomyosarcomas • Acute leukemia The following is the image of neuroblastoma showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. 208 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is a disorganized but benign mass composed of cells indigenous to the 
involved site?
questions.explanation:
Hamartomas are disorganized but benign, masses composed of cells indigenous to the involved 
site. Examples of hamartoma include: • Mammary hamartoma • Pulmonary chondromatous hamartoma • Splenic hamartoma • Neurocristic hamartoma • Fibrous hamartoma of infancy Option A: Choristomas are heterotopic rests of cells. Option D: Teratomas arise from totipotent germ cells. They contain recognizable mature or 
immature cells or tissues belonging to more than one germ cell layer, and sometimes all three 
germ layers. Option C: Papillomas are benign epithelial neoplasms. They are characterized by microscopically 
or macroscopically visible finger-like or warty projections from epithelial surfaces.

questions.question:
Question 6: While examining an excision biopsy sample, the pathologist notices anaplastic cells. Which of 
the following tumors will show this characteristic finding?
questions.explanation:
Anaplasia or lack of differentiation is a characteristic feature of malignant neoplasm like sarcoma. Differentiation refers to the extent to which neoplastic parenchymal cells resemble the 
corresponding normal parenchymal cells, both morphologically and functionally. 209 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows a hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by large anaplastic carcinoma 
cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. The 
normal trabecular structure of the liver is distorted.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio?
questions.explanation:
The normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4 to 1:6. Normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio implies that the volume occupied by the cytoplasm is 4 to 6 
times greater than the volume occupied by the nucleus. Abnormal nuclear morphologies that are seen in malignant cells: • Nuclei disproportionately large for the cell • Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular • Chromatin • Coarsely clumped • Hyperchromatic • Nucleoli are abnormally large

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer. Which of the following 
features is least likely to be seen in the microscopic examination of the resected tumor?
questions.explanation:
Loss of polarity is a microscopic finding in malignant neoplasm, like metastatic breast cancer. In malignancy, the orientation of cells is markedly disturbed, and polarity is lost. Sheets or large 
masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion. Morphological changes in cancer cells: • Anaplasia 210 
Sold by @itachibot • Pleomorphism • Nuclear changes • Nuclei disproportionately large for the cell • Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular • Chromatin - coarsely clumped and hyperchromatic • Nucleoli are abnormally large • Atypical mitosis • Loss of polarity

questions.question:
Question 9: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of post-coital bleeding. On per speculum 
examination, a friable mass is seen and a punch biopsy is done. The presence of which of the 
following features in microscopic examination of biopsy specimen differentiates invasive 
carcinoma from carcinoma in situ?
questions.explanation:
Once the tumor cells breach the basement membrane, the tumor is said to be invasive. Progression of cancer occurs in the following stages: dysplasiacarcinoma in situinvasive 
carcinoma In situ carcinoma is when dysplastic changes are marked and involve the full thickness of the 
epithelium, but the lesion does not penetrate the basement membrane. It is a pre-invasive 
neoplasm. The tumor is said to be invasive when the basement membrane is breached by the tumor cells.

questions.question: Question 10: Choose the correct statement(s):

options.a: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
options.b: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
options.c: A is true; R is false
options.d: A is false; R is true

questions.explanation:
All tumors with invasive property (malignant tumors) may not necessarily metastasize. Examples of tumors with invasive properties but do not metastasize are: • Gliomas • Basal cell carcinomas of the skin Both of these cancers invade early in their course, but rarely metastasize. Thus, it is evident then 
that the properties of invasion and metastasis are separable.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 40-year-old patient is diagnosed with a breast lump. On clinical examination, nodes are not 
palpable. Mammography is suggestive of a malignant tumor. Which of the following nodes is 
often biopsied to assess the presence of metastasis microscopically?

options.a: Largest lymph node in the region of the primary tumor
options.b: Smallest lymph node in the region of the primary tumor
options.c: First lymph node that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor
options.d: Last lymph node that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor

questions.explanation:
The sentinel lymph node, which is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph 
flow from the primary tumor, is often used to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions 
in the lymph nodes microscopically. Sentinel node mapping can be done by the injection of radiolabeled tracers or colored dyes. 
Examination of frozen sections of the sentinel lymph node is often performed during surgery. It 
can guide the surgeon to the appropriate therapy. 211 
Sold by @itachibot Sentinel node examination has also been used for detecting the spread of: • Melanomas • Colon cancers

Question 12: 203 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not an angiogenesis promoter in tumor cells?
questions.explanation:
Thrombospondin is an anti-angiogenic factor. Angiogenic and antiangiogenic factors are produced by tumor and stromal cells and are essential 
for the vascularization of tumors. Angiogenic activators include: • Angiogenin • Interleukin-8 • Growth factors: • Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) • Basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) • Transforming growth factor (TGF)- and  • Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)- • Platelet-derived endothelial growth factor • Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor • Placental growth factor • Hepatocyte growth factor • Epidermal growth factor Anti-angiogenic factors include: 212 
Sold by @itachibot • Angiostatin • Endostatin • Interferon • Platelet factor 4 • Thrombospondin • Prolactin 16 KD fragment • Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-1, 2, and 3

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following malignancies is least likely to occur in those with only alcohol abuse 
and without any additional risk factors?
questions.explanation:
Alcohol abuse alone increases the risk of carcinomas of the oropharynx (excluding lip), larynx, and 
esophagus. Alcohol and tobacco together synergistically increase the risk of cancers in the upper airway and 
digestive tract.

questions.question:
Question 14: A textile factory worker who is repeatedly exposed to benzene is at increased risk of 
developing which of the following tumors?
questions.explanation:
Repeated exposure to benzene is associated with increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) Malignancies associated with repeated exposure to benzene: • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) • Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). • Multiple myeloma. Note: While studies have shown that benzene has a propensity to cause bladder carcinoma , it is 
most commonly associated with AMLs.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 60-year-old patient employed in plastic industry for 30 years is diagnosed with a tumor in 
the liver. On resection, the gross specimen shows greyish white lesions with multiple 
reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces shown by arrows in the image

questions.question:
Question 16: A 50-year-old patient is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. Which of the following is implicated 
in the causation of this tumor?
questions.explanation: Radon is implicated in the causation of lung carcinoma. Carcinogens implicated in lung carcinoma are: • Asbestos • Arsenic • Beryllium • Chromium • Nickel • Radon.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of cholangiocarcinoma presents with intermittent 
fever and jaundice. Which of the following organisms is commonly implicated in the 
pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.explanation: Opisthorchis viverrini (liver fluke) is implicated in the pathogenesis of cholangiocarcinoma. Apart from Opisthorchis viverrini, Clonorchis sinensis is also known to cause cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is the least radiosensitive cell in blood?
questions.explanation:
The least radiosensitive cell in the blood is the platelet. The most radiosensitive cell in the blood is the lymphocyte. 214 
Sold by @itachibot The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is G2M. The least radiosensitive is the S phase. 215 
Sold by @itachibot Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity
